snippet.textDisplay: This, Chrono Trigger, Breath of Fire 2, Twewy and FFTA are my favourite Games for Nintendo consoles. The idea behind the remake wasn't bad, but it was lacking in many places. The technical limitations of 3D, the UI, Lexis being Mr Exposition but not having the ability to explain how any of his inventions work are just a few. Also the level design had many objects that felt really out of place. Brightly coloured raising plattforms in the wilderness, futuristic doors next to wooden logs, etc. If they had had 3 month more to work on it, it could have been a nice game.

snippet.textDisplay:
@iuri Lua Don't worry about answering me late. I myself wasn't sure your comment merited a response, but now I think it does.

It is possible to get across some moderate leftist messages without resorting to sacrificing genuine artistic merit, but if a message, left- or right-wing, just can't be in media without it feeling heavy-handed, it's a pretty good indication that that message specifically is a bad one. This poor grasp of art also might have to do with people making well-intentioned but misguided attempts to appease people who either get offended at something no matter what, or pretend to be offended to shut down art they don't like. The latter group also don't seem to understand that what is bad for them might be good for someone else. But other than that, your analysis was right on.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have the book, it's called _Mastering Manga with Mark Crilley_ (the author also made Akiko). It assumes you know what the nose and mouth are supposed to look like but teaches you the right way to draw everything anyway. I'm glad to help an artist with their art.

CrossCode and Secrets of Grindea both have the same type of character art with big anime eyes but overly defined noses and mouths, but I can't find anyone complaining about any overpowering ideology in either game. So no, now that I look at more games with "fake anime" art I don't think this is entirely a left-authoritarian or even general radical ideologue problem. It's more of a general but not universal misconception about what anime art is like outside East Asia.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Ambrose Burnout I see, I agree with you but I was referring to the artists point of view, not the consumer's. Often enough I see western artists trying to incorporate the anime style in their art and failing somehow at it. Take Time Spinner for example, the portrait art is confusing, it seems to try the anime style/or a cartoon hybrid (fancy hair colors, big eyes) but the artist seems clueless as to "what" make anime style what it is, so he/she doesn't notice he's making the character portraits too realistic (well defined nose, mouth and general facial structure) at the point it seems kind of ugly (some players have even said they didn't knew the protagonist was a female), whereas the essence of the anime style is basically being cute as a priority, thus the facial features becoming less defined and more simplified aiming at cuteness.
Well, that's just an opinion from another artist (myself), because of course there are several western artists who make awesome anime art and hybrids in the likes of it, but it's interesting to see some artists showing those tendencies more than others.
